awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Cross-Linguistic Investigations of the Acquisition of Subject-Verb Agreement
awd_abstract_narration:
Subject-verb agreement is pervasive in many languages and it is one of the earliest syntactic relations that children must master. Prior research has suggested that its course of acquisition is different in different languages: early production but late comprehension have been observed in English, Spanish and Xhosa (Bantu) while production and comprehension are both early in French (by 30 months of age). The PIs in this collaborative project, Dr. Legendre and Dr. Barriere, seek to reconcile these results by evaluating the hypothesis that children can detect agreement markers better and earlier in languages in which these markers are both perceptually salient and semantically transparent.
 
The research project will target four languages chosen because their relevant properties allow a number of factors to be teased apart: English, Spanish, French, and Haitian Creole. This project is innovative in seeking to investigate the role of perceptual factors, both at the sentential level and cross-linguistically, and fosters interdisciplinary approaches to the study of language acquisition by melding research in theoretical syntax, psycholinguistics, corpus analysis, and speech perception, and combining their respective research methods.  The project will stimulate international collaborations between the PIs in the US and research consultants in France, and will provide valuable research experience for a post-doctoral researcher, and for graduate and undergraduate students at the two US sites.

por.por_cntn:
This project in language learning documents early steps in mastering a native language by examining their detailed development in several languages. By carrying out a cross-linguistic investigation focusing in about 900 monolingual children and using in a novel way the same experimental procedures and visual stimuli paired with language-specific verbal stimuli pertaining to the same linguistic aspect, singular vs. plural subject-verb agreement, it has been possible to identify what makes this ubiquitous aspect of language easier or harder to detect, understand, and master. Evidence of emerging new knowledge and/or mastery was gathered in several facets of language learning between the ages of 14 and 36 months. Children's comprehension was measured through their preference for pairing a plural sentence with a plural scene, and a singular sentence with a singular scene, displayed before the child.  Their ability to discriminate correct from incorrect subject-verb agreement as early as 14 months was measured in terms of their listening preference for either. Their production of subject-verb agreement was measured via the analysis of spontaneous speech in an interactive context with a parent, and in lab-based elicitation tasks.  The complementarity of results has allowed us to establish milestones for normal development in English, Spanish, and French. These results can now inform the development of assessment tools to be used by clinicians and educators to identify language learning delays and promote early intervention. 

The project provided STEM-related research and professional training to a number of undergraduate and graduate students as well as a post-doctoral researcher.
